comments.author: pds
comments.content: There are lots of great youtube videos on how to pleat dumplings.  I watched several and learned right away.  I've been practicing for a year now, making dumplings every other month or so, and have gotten quite fast.  It's worth it.

comments.author: KSE
comments.content: For those in NYC, I have seen dumpling presses at M2M on 3rd ave between 10th and 11th.  One thing I've noticed with mandoo, however, is that the wrapper/skin tends to be thicker than other dumplings--which I think sets mandoo apart.  Do you have any suggestions for brand that has a thicker wrapper, or perhaps a recipe for one?

comments.author: satsumabug
comments.content: Oooh, I love mandoo. All the ones I've ever had seem to be very oniony, and that sets them apart from the Chinese ones. Do you think your recipe would work with all tempeh? I don't eat tofu.

comments.author: BigGirlPhoebz
comments.content: These look excellent! we have become obsessed with Andrea Nguyen's dumplings. In fact, the last time we made them, we served them alongside the momofuku bo ssam! You have to try the ginger scallion sauce--it's to die for.

comments.author: thepinkpeppercorn
comments.content: mmm!  I am so intrigued!  I have the momofuku book, but haven't made this sauce yet - and your dumplings sound spectacular!!

comments.author: maybelles mom
comments.content: when i read that your daughter was a whizz at the press, I really thought about getting one.  we are on a spending freeze for a while, but it is on my list.  These are just very yum.

comments.author: hanna
comments.content: any mandu that's pan-fried will be called gunmandu, so i'd probably just call these dooboo somandu, which is literally "tofu, veggie-stuffedmandu" or somandu. I suppose that you could put the word for fried before all of that and end up with something like gun dooboo somandu. if interested, one of the most common somandu recipes involves the use of tofu and minari (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oenanthe_javanica). This is definitely one of my favorite types of mandu!

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content:
Hey - thanks for your comment! I do use a brand that is labeled "extra thick" but I haven't noticed the name. I'll try and remember to notice next time I go to get them.

Thanks,
Michael

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: Yep, this will absolutely work with all tempeh! See also the alternative recipe linked at the top of the article.

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: Hanna, thanks so much for the great information!

comments.author: Sarah
comments.content: looks delicious, funny how they look exactly like kreplach, my all time favorite Polish food.

comments.author: ronit
comments.content: ahhhh i want that new toy i mean dumpling press so baddd!!!!! "none available" on amazon...guess i'll browse around on ebay

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: Try this one, it should be about the same, and equally cheap: http://amzn.to/b9sm2g

comments.author: Miles
comments.content: Sorry to bring this topic back up after so long, but do you have a preferred place/brand for gochujang in Seattle?  I looked around and could only find ones where the first ingredient is corn syrup.  Are there some more natural ones around here?

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: Hi Miles - I don't have a box near me (I'm at a coffee shop right now), but I'm pretty sure the one I buy at Uwajimaya in the red tub doesn't have corn syrup as the first ingredient! I'm sure it is on there somewhere, but the top few ingredients should certainly be soybeans, chilis and wheat. Oh, here's a pic of the box I managed to google: http://www.meilengloh.com/?p=248

comments.author: Peggy
comments.content: I grew up with mandu and gochujang. I wouldn't get too hung up on the brand, but I agree: do look at the ingredients. Gochujang comes either in plastic tubs or glass jars: buy the container you prefer that has a product with ingredients that seem reasonable to you.

comments.author: Michelle
comments.content:
Dumpling press has arrived! Mandu making happening this weekend.
I'm curious  if anyone has tried these out in a soup. How long would I simmer them for? Should I steam them first? I'm thinking they might be outta this world with Michael's Umami-Packed Broth...add a little of the kochujang sauce.

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: I haven't, but I like your thought process! I'd even consider pan-frying them first to develop flavor, then adding them to soup at last minute to preserve a bit of crisp. If you try it, let us know how it turns out!
